What's a "toolkit"?

An introduction to toolkit-driven development

Style guide vs toolkit

Website style guides have evolved over the years, starting as an outreach of the tradition (print) branding style guides, eventually maturing into great examples of how a brand should be look and feel on the web. Starbucks, Yelp, Salesforce, Code For America, and Google's Material Design have some of the best web style guides around.

A toolkit is more focused on code - specifically the modularity of website components. Toolkits break down websites into small, repeatable components, then use those components to build an infinite number of layouts. Twitter Bootstrap, Topcoat, and Zurb's Foundation are popular toolkits.

Both are great and can be extremely useful. Fabricator gives you a way to combine both concepts into one deliverable.

When you work with Fabricator, you develop a brand's look and feel on the web, while also producing a code toolkit that you'll use when building their digital properties.

Fabricator is developed by @LukeAskew
